timeline.bodyText: Should this span be the active span at this time? If so, this lambda wouldn't need to capture here.
timeline.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: It seems unfortunate that we go to such lengths and quite some cost to propagate context into completable futures, when all we really need to do is capture the span in a closure, but we're doing both here, the CompletableFuture instrumentation should be making sure this would be the active span at the time.
replies.author: richardstartin

timeline.bodyText: may or may not be worth it, but this will autobox, RadixTreeCache.PORTS.get(((InetSocketAddress) address).getPort()) works around this.
timeline.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: @richardstartin would it be worth adding special logic for this in the setTag(String,int) method?
replies.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: That seems dangerous to me. Here, we know it's a port, and that it only has 16 bits, that it isn't negative, so can reason about worst cases. Elsewhere, it could be any integer.
replies.author: richardstartin

replies.bodyText: I changed the code to just call the other version BaseDecorator.onPeerConnection().  I'll update that in a separate PR
replies.author: randomanderson

timeline.bodyText: Do we want to add a secondary name to distinguish 3 from 4?
timeline.author: tylerbenson

timeline.bodyText: Ideally the package name should distinguish to avoid potential naming conflicts with 3. (Maybe update the 3.x package too?)
timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: ah, yes.  I've been bitten by this quirk before
replies.author: randomanderson

timeline.bodyText: Since your advice is focused on the return type instead of arguments, consider a return type matcher (perhaps instead of the argument matcher).
timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: I'll add a return type matcher for defensive programming but there are 2 init methods with the same return type so the argument matcher needs to stay
replies.author: randomanderson
